accepted in revised form 9 February 1995 Abstract The cation-exchange equilibrium for amino acid cation-hydrogen ion was reported in detail, the thermodynamic functions for the ion exchange of 10 amino acid cations at low pH were determined. The thermodynamic analysis of ion exchange of amino acid cation gives valuable insight into ion exchange of peptides and proteins. Keywords: Ion exchange; Amino acid; Thermodynamic function 1. Introduction Although numerous papers in the literature have reported the use of ion exchange for analytical or large-scale separation of amino acids, up to now no systematic investigation of thermodynamic functions for the ion exchange of amino acids with hydrogen appears to have been reported. There have only been a few systematic investigations of ion-exchange equilibrium properties of amino acids. Seno and Yamabe [1,2] have examined the equilibrium uptake of a number of amino acids by both cation- and anion-exchange resins in a single-component system. Feitelson [3,4] has carried out studies on the uptake of amino acids at their isoelectric pH by a cation-exchange resin, in the presence of a large excess of buffer. Yu and Wang [5] and Yu et al. [6] have reported the effects of equilibrium on the dynamics of chromatographic columns used for the separation of amino acids. Saunders et * Corresponding author. 1381-5148/95/$09.50 1995 Elsevier Science B.V All rights reserved. SSDI 1381-5148(95)00027-5 al. [7] have employed a complex model and derived the equations for ion exchange of amino acids in unbuffered solution. Wang et al. [8] have presented a much simpler model for uptake of amino acids at given pH. Helfferich [9] derived the equations describing equilibrium uptake of amino acids by strong acid cation-exchange resin as a function of pH and concentrations of amino acid and added electrolyte or buffer. All amino acids have one a-amino group, one a-carboxy group, and a side chain (R). According to their side functional groups, amino acids can be classified into neutral, acidic and basic amino acids. The structure of amino acids can be generally represented as NHZCHRCOOH. In aqueous solution the following equilibrium protonation reactions of neutral amino acids [7,10] take place: NH3CHRCOO- +H+ OHI NHSCHRCOOH Kl 30 Z. For amino acids that have an ionizable R group, an additional dissociation reaction should be considered. Basic amino acids have a basic side chain, in aqueous solution, the two positively charged species exist at low pH values. Acidic amino acids have an acidic side chain, only one positively charged species exists at low pH values in aqueous solution. The aims of this paper are: (1) to determine the thermodynamic functions for the ion exchange of amino acids with hydrogen at pH < pKl; and (2) to understand the fundamental ion-exchange behavior of amino acids. A strong acid cation-exchange resin was chosen for this study because its charge density and capacity do not change with pH. Seven neutral amino acids (L-Trp, L-Phe, L-Ser, L-Leu, D,L-Thr, LAla and L-Gly), one acidic amino acid (L-Glu) and two basic amino acids (L-Lys and L-Arg) were studied in a given pH range, and within the pH range tested, the amino groups are always positively charged. 2. Experimental 2.1. Materials 001X7 resin (sulfonate polystyrene resin, 0.02-0.04 cm radius, 7% DVB, made in Shanghai Resin Factory) was used. Prior to the experiment, the resin was pretreated by repeated washes with NaOH and HCl solutions, converted to the hydrogen form with 1 N HCI, and thoroughly rinsed with distilled deionized water. It was then put on a shallow glass dish placed inside the desiccator over the saturated NaCI solution until a constant weight was reached. The desiccator was placed in a thermostat (25 2). The capacity of this resin was 3.69 t 0.02 mEq/g. All of the amino acids were purchased from Cheng Don Chemicals Factory and Shanghai Institute of Biochemistry, and were biochemical reagents. All of the amino acids were obtained in crystalline form, used without further purification and made a previous analysis by means of titration in glacial acetic acid. Using a TRONAC Model 1250 automatic microtitration calorimeter, enthalpy changes of the protonation of amino acids and of the sorption of amino acids at isoelectric pH were obtained. 2.2. Procedure 2.2.1. Equilibrium experiment The amino acid solutions were prepared with distilled deionized water and the pH values (<pKl) were adjusted with 1 M HCI. The equilibrium experiments were performed by the batch method at 25 1. The weighted amounts of resin were first placed in a glass-stoppered flask, with a definite volume of the amino acid solution added, the flasks were shaken gently for 1 week or more until no further change in solution composition was to be noted. After equilibration, aliquots of the resultant solution were pipetted off and analyzed to determine the total concentration of amino acid and pH value. The total concentrations of amino acid in equilibrium solutions were determined colorimetrically with ninhydrin as chromogen [11] by spectrophotometer Model 721 (made in Shanghai Third Analysis Instrument Factory), the equilibrium pH values were measured with a pHS-3 type pH meter (made in Shanghai Second Analysis Instrument Factory). The amino acid concentration and hydrogen ion concentration of the resin phase were then calculated from the total resin capacities and the initial and final concentrations of the solution phases. Z. An amount of 25 ml of 0.05 M amino acid solution was pipetted into 25-ml Dewar flasks placed in the calorimetric system. HCl solution was the titrant. The reactive solution was thermostated at 298.15 0.03 K by means of a thermistor in the water bath, and then the input executive statement to automatic microtitration calorimeter and enthalpy changes of the protonation of amino acids' caCOO- were obtained by fitting the calorimetric curves. Forty points were required for every calorimetric curve. The titration rate was 0.1049 ml/18 s for each point and the time that elapsed between successive additions of HCl solution was 30 s which was suggested by the preliminary experiments. Discussion As can be seen from column 5 of Table 1, it is of particular interest that the positive enthalpy change sign appears for every amino acid, and this result demonstrates that the interactions between the amino acid cations and the fixed ionic groups are weaker than the interactions between the hydrogen ion and the fixed ionic groups. The simplest interpretation of the positive enthalpy effect (a positive change in enthalpy) seems to be that it is due to a steric hindrance when an amino acid cation approaches a fixed ionic group and the weak electrostatic interaction between a large amino acid cation and a fixed ionic group. Though there is usually an additional interaction between organic ions and the ion-exchange resin [12], it is too weak to compensate the decrease in electrostatic interaction energy. The distinctive aspect of amino acid cationhydrogen ion exchange for pH < pK1 is the rise in entropy for every system (column 6 of Table 1), and the positive entropy effect (a positive change in entropy), must obviously be due to the additional microstates that appear as a result of local weak additional interaction between amino acid and ion-exchange resin and of the complex structure of amino acid as compared with the small mineral ion. A set of weak interactions at low energy leads to the appearance of a series of microstates for the resinate of amino acid cation and to an increased system entropy. As mentioned above, the positive enthalpy effect indicates that the selectivity for the amino acid is attributed to the positive entropy effect, and the gain in enthalpy is not fully reflected in an equivalent increase of the free energy changes due to concomitant changes in the entropy of same sign as the OHH. On the basis of the above results and discussion, it may be concluded that: (1) the ionexchange behavior of amino acid is much more complex than that of small mineral ion; (2) the thermodynamic analysis of ion-exchange of amino acid cation gives valuable insight into the ion exchange of peptides and proteins. However, 33 the challenging question of whether the overall thermodynamic quantity can be separated into contributions from electrostatic and dispersion forces, hydrophobic interactions, and hydrogen bonds, cannot be answered by this investiga- tion.
